s.text: 7The general issue of crediting the work of others: Gates objects most strongly to the assertion that "there is something dishonest about marketing under Gates' signature work that is produced mainly by his assistants."
Franklin Foer's "Henry Louis Gates Jr.: The Academic as Entrepreneur" is nice about my own work, but it gets so many things wrong that it makes me feel for poor Belemjian.

7The general issue of crediting the work of others: Gates objects most strongly to the assertion that "there is something dishonest about marketing under Gates' signature work that is produced mainly by his assistants."
Franklin Foer's "Henry Louis Gates Jr.: The Academic as Entrepreneur" is nice about my own work, but it gets so many things wrong that it makes me feel for poor Belemjian.
"Absolutely true," the radio announcer replies.
I didn't serve on 29 journal boards and 82 advisory committees over the course of one year, as Slate suggests, but over the course of some 22 years.

2. The "chief of staff": Not only did Glenshaw identify himself to Franklin Foer as the chief of staff, but others confirmed Glenshaw often refers to himself that way.
Sadly, the life of Reilly Slate evokes is no life of mine.
Granted they do not work full time on the projects I described in my article, but I don't think Gates will deny they perform these tasks.
Whether that is a fair conclusion to draw from the evidence is something the reader, once again, can decide.
Whether that is a fair conclusion to draw from the evidence is something the reader, once again, can decide.
Nevertheless, we want to get things right and be as fair as possible.
Obviously, when his vitae says he no longer serves on a board, I didn't include it in my tally.

1. The CV on which Gates says no one could possibly suppose he was trying to imply he is currently on those boards: We accept that he was not trying to imply this, but you wouldn't be insane to infer it--especially given that some boards do list a leaving date.
I didn't serve on 29 journal boards and 82 advisory committees over the course of one year, as Slate suggests, but over the course of some 22 years.

1. The CV on which Gates says no one could possibly suppose he was trying to imply he is currently on those boards: We accept that he was not trying to imply this, but you wouldn't be insane to infer it--especially given that some boards do list a leaving date.
My vitae lists the advisory committees and editorial boards I've participated in since 1976.
For the article, Gates asked not to be quoted about the Encyclopedia because of a nondisclosure agreement with Microsoft.
For the article, Gates asked not to be quoted about the Encyclopedia because of a nondisclosure agreement with Microsoft.
The editor of Slate has often asked others to track down a quote, sees nothing wrong with it (as long as you ask politely), and doesn't believe the article suggested there was anything wrong with it.
But, Slate protests, "it was [Gates'] byline that appeared on the cover."
